result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Benjamin Scott Monahan

records.addlTxt: RTS/UTF
RTS/UTF
Bail to be set at no less than $5,000 cash.

8:38 AM Defendant Benjamin Scott Monahan not in court.  Attorney Lance Morgan Nelsen in court for Benjamin Scott Monahan.  Attorney Mark Adam Fruehauf in court for State of Wisconsin. Court notes that a bail notice was signed by the defendant for appearance today. Attorney Nelsen has no information on the nonappearance. Upon defendants failure to appear, State requests warrant and forfeiture of any bond. Asks for bail to be set at no less than $5,000 when the defendant is picked up. State will have restitution order submitted, asks that bail be applied to restitution if bail is forfeited. Court grants warrant, WI and adjoining states, and forfeiture of any bond previously ordered. Court grants states request that cash bail be ordered in no less than $5,000 when he appears. Forfeited bail to be applied to restitution.

records.addlTxt: 09:46 AM Defendant Benjamin Scott Monahan in court and not in-custody with attorney Lance Morgan Nelsen who appears telephonically.  Mark Adam Fruehauf appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Court calls case. Attorney states their client wishes to waive their right to the preliminary hearing. Defendant agrees. Court accepts waiver of the Defendants right to a preliminary hearing as knowingly, understandingly, and voluntarily made. Court finds probable case and binds the defendant over for arraignment. Court reminds the Defendant of bail conditions. Defendant provided notice.  Arraignment scheduled for May 23, 2022 at 09:00 am.
